description: The Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP) certification is the gold standard in the IT Security field. Security professionals that have achieved their CISSP designation are regarded as some of the most talented and knowledgeable people in their field. The certification is demonstrates that the holder has been working in IT Security for over five years and has a broad range of knowledge in ten domains related to creating, supporting and maintaining a secure IT infrastructure.
name: Certified Information Systems Security Professional
subtitle: CISSP

episodes.description: Adam and Don introduce the viewers to the CISSP certification. They describe what content is covered by the exam, what prior knowledge you should have, and the requirements to apply for the certification once you pass the exam. They then break down the 10 topic areas that will be covered throughout the show.
episodes.title: Overview of CISSP

The concepts, methodologies,

139
00:07:29,080 --> 00:07:30,370

141

Well we move to telecommunications and

146

147

00:07:53,769 --> 00:07:54,803

149
00:07:54,803 --> 00:07:59,946
In order to better understand

150

and solutions such as DMZs, right?

151
00:08:06,262 --> 00:08:08,842
Firewalls, things of this
nature will be discussed.

152
00:08:08,842 --> 00:08:13,220
And we will obviously broadly stretch
that out across the entire architecture.

153
00:08:13,220 --> 00:08:16,470
Both from the local area as well as in
the wide area into our perspective.

154
00:08:16,470 --> 00:08:19,330
So literally from the LAN to the WAN and
back again.

155
00:08:19,330 --> 00:08:23,190
Information security governance and
risk management focuses on

156
00:08:23,190 --> 00:08:27,680
more of the policy areas associated

157
00:08:27,680 --> 00:08:32,000
We're really looking there at
security governance and policy and

158
00:08:32,000 --> 00:08:36,779
the guides that it provides to us in
terms of the ways in which we're able to

159
00:08:36,779 --> 00:08:41,812

160
00:08:41,812 --> 00:08:45,205
And really this idea of awareness
within the business and

161
00:08:45,205 --> 00:08:49,190
among the user communities that
are making up the community.

162
00:08:49,190 --> 00:08:53,107
Or the information security management
focus, the community of interest that

163
00:08:53,107 --> 00:08:55,509
the business or
your practice may be focused on.

164
00:08:55,509 --> 00:09:00,152
So classification and ownership of data,
the ideas of risk management, business

165
00:09:00,152 --> 00:09:04,395
impact analysis and how we see the two
working together to help us to create,

166
00:09:04,395 --> 00:09:08,441
not only awareness, but guidance
around that awareness from a policy,

167
00:09:08,441 --> 00:09:11,535
from a standards, and
from a guideline perspective.

168
00:09:11,535 --> 00:09:15,030
And we will talk about those things and
how they all come together.

169
00:09:15,030 --> 00:09:19,154
Software development security, we refer
to the idea of a software development or

170
00:09:19,154 --> 00:09:21,150
a system development life cycle.

171
00:09:21,150 --> 00:09:25,160
You can see SDLC is listed there
as one of the sub bullet points.

172
00:09:25,160 --> 00:09:29,916
All the control elements included
within the software and/or system life

173
00:09:29,916 --> 00:09:33,853
cycle to build a holistic secure solution,
start to finish.

174
00:09:33,853 --> 00:09:37,894
From the idea of really thinking
through it from the inception phase.

175
00:09:37,894 --> 00:09:41,711
Thinking through the strategies
associated with aligning value and

176
00:09:41,711 --> 00:09:46,052
business requirements all the way through
to the proof of concept, the actual

177
00:09:46,052 --> 00:09:50,280
tactical steps involved with defining and
then building an architecture.

178
00:09:50,280 --> 00:09:53,790
And then actually managing and
manipulating that system,

179
00:09:53,790 --> 00:09:58,279
monitoring it in real time through its
end of life cycle as we cycle it down and

180
00:09:58,279 --> 00:10:01,240
replace it in whatever that
form may be over time.

181
00:10:01,240 --> 00:10:04,890
And so that entire system life cycle
is what we will speak about here.

182
00:10:04,890 --> 00:10:09,510
Very interesting topic, one of the topics
where a lot of the practitioners that

183
00:10:09,510 --> 00:10:13,870
come in looking to certify as CISSPs may
or may not have a lot of background.

184
00:10:13,870 --> 00:10:17,310
This is one of those areas that you either
do this and you really do it for a living,

185
00:10:17,310 --> 00:10:18,310
understand it.

186
00:10:18,310 --> 00:10:21,608
Typical roles that we would
see as job holders here.

187
00:10:21,608 --> 00:10:24,920
Maybe business analysts,
maybe project managers,

188
00:10:24,920 --> 00:10:29,490
a PMO type of people that focus on change,
focus on portfolio management.

189
00:10:29,490 --> 00:10:35,330
Certainly business analysts that will do
usage acceptance testing, UAT, that would

190
00:10:35,330 --> 00:10:40,570
be focused on universal languages such as
UML for modeling business case scenarios.

191
00:10:40,570 --> 00:10:42,720
These are people that tend to focus in and

192
00:10:42,720 --> 00:10:44,730
really have an understanding
of these areas.

193
00:10:44,730 --> 00:10:47,821
If you have a background with
agile scrum or waterfall,

194
00:10:47,821 --> 00:10:51,048
as methodological solutions

195
00:10:51,048 --> 00:10:54,870
you probably have a specialty area,

196
00:10:54,870 --> 00:10:56,160
But if you're not in that space,

197
00:10:56,160 --> 00:10:59,920
this is one of those areas where we
spend time helping you to understand it.

198
00:10:59,920 --> 00:11:03,080
You get familiar with it enough certainly
to understand the material to ultimately

199
00:11:03,080 --> 00:11:07,700

200
00:11:07,700 --> 00:11:11,010
But you may not spend a lot of
time doing this kind of work

201
00:11:11,010 --> 00:11:13,820
in your day to day practice and
that's okay.

202
00:11:13,820 --> 00:11:16,620
You don't have to be

00:11:16,620 --> 00:11:18,760
You don't even have to
like all these areas.

204
00:11:18,760 --> 00:11:21,360
Although we would want to encourage

205
00:11:21,360 --> 00:11:25,210
And be focused on them in the relation to

206
00:11:25,210 --> 00:11:28,840

like threat and vulnerability and

207

00:11:31,730 --> 00:11:35,380
But you don't have to do SDLC

209
00:11:35,380 --> 00:11:38,380
And so be aware of the fact that there
will be some things you like on the menu,

just like anything else,
some things you may not be as happy with.

211
00:11:41,630 --> 00:11:44,560
Some things you put off to the side and
go, there's absolutely no way.

212
00:11:44,560 --> 00:11:48,245
But at the end of the day,
you have to have some level of comfort and

213
00:11:48,245 --> 00:11:52,672
knowledge in all ten of these areas to
be successful at passing the CISSP exam.

214
00:11:52,672 --> 00:11:56,220
Then after that you go back to the real
world in terms of your practice.

215
00:11:56,220 --> 00:11:58,970
Your focus on your day to
day activities in your jobs.

216
00:11:58,970 --> 00:12:00,800
And you will then further specialize and

And others may, as a result,

219
00:12:07,210 --> 00:12:12,110
Cryptography, the idea of applying the
principles, as it says, their means and

220
00:12:12,110 --> 00:12:16,690
methods of disguising information to
ensure not just authenticity, but

221
00:12:16,690 --> 00:12:19,425
integrity, and ultimately confidentiality.

222
00:12:19,425 --> 00:12:21,975
And so
we wanna really focus on keeping data

223
00:12:21,975 --> 00:12:25,455
away from people that don't need to see
it, don't have the right to see it here.

224
00:12:25,455 --> 00:12:29,665
But ensuring proof of origin,
ensuring integrity in our data,

225
00:12:29,665 --> 00:12:33,265
non repudiation in our data streams,
which is proof of origin.

226
00:12:33,265 --> 00:12:37,965
And so things such as digital signatures,
things such as hashing, PKI,

227
00:12:37,965 --> 00:12:41,285
public key infrastructure,
all of that is discussed here.

228
00:12:41,285 --> 00:12:42,955
And we will spend time going through and

229
00:12:42,955 --> 00:12:47,170
helping you to better understand the way
in which this kind of a solution

230
00:12:47,170 --> 00:12:49,730
can be built into the architecture
of your systems from the ground up.

231
00:12:51,070 --> 00:12:53,820
We take a look at security
architecture and design.

232
00:12:53,820 --> 00:12:57,090
The principle structures and
strategies that help us monitor and

233
00:12:57,090 --> 00:13:00,020
secure not only operating
systems as it says there, but

234
00:13:00,020 --> 00:13:02,790
all of the building blocks and
components of our network.

235
00:13:02,790 --> 00:13:06,570
So the equipment, the software,
the logical, physical, and

236
00:13:06,570 --> 00:13:09,220
technical controls that
are brought to bear there.

237
00:13:09,220 --> 00:13:11,880
So things such as virtualization.

238
00:13:11,880 --> 00:13:16,325
Things such as cloud computing,
big topic today, often misunderstood,

239
00:13:16,325 --> 00:13:20,900
misrepresented, and not always very
easily identified and defined.

240
00:13:20,900 --> 00:13:22,030
Good marketing concept.

241
00:13:22,030 --> 00:13:25,910
Very unsure of what that may
mean in our world sometimes.

242
00:13:25,910 --> 00:13:27,300
But what are security models?

243
00:13:27,300 --> 00:13:29,080
Right?
What are vulnerabilities and threats?

244
00:13:29,080 --> 00:13:31,220
What are countermeasures
we can bring to bear?

245
00:13:31,220 --> 00:13:33,660
And how do we build security
in from every level and

246
00:13:33,660 --> 00:13:36,550
every angle of our design
from the ground up?

247
00:13:36,550 --> 00:13:38,130
Operational security.

248
00:13:38,130 --> 00:13:41,620
This is where we tend to see a lot of
people having background in one of

249
00:13:41,620 --> 00:13:42,366
these areas.

250
00:13:42,366 --> 00:13:46,265
Such as operational security,
where we see that most people have some

251
00:13:46,265 --> 00:13:49,982
sort of exposure to physical security,
another area down below.

252
00:13:49,982 --> 00:13:53,794
And we kind of blend these two together,
where we talk about how we do resource

253
00:13:53,794 --> 00:13:57,903
protection, incident response, and then
what are the things that are associated

254
00:13:57,903 --> 00:14:02,264
with that from a prevention and a tracking
and vulnerability management perspective.

255
00:14:02,264 --> 00:14:04,958
And so that's what we see
in operational security.

256
00:14:04,958 --> 00:14:09,310
BCP, business continuity planning,
DRP, disaster recovery planning,

257
00:14:09,310 --> 00:14:14,340
another area that is usually a specialty
of certain people in a business.

258
00:14:14,340 --> 00:14:16,810
This is the area where we talk about

259
00:14:16,810 --> 00:14:20,540
how do we deal with
the possibility of an impact?

260
00:14:20,540 --> 00:14:23,300
And then if we do have this threat,
this vulnerability,

261
00:14:23,300 --> 00:14:27,370
this risk become realized,
what do we do to get back to normal?

262
00:14:27,370 --> 00:14:28,430
And so, we look at the what if,

263
00:14:28,430 --> 00:14:32,940
and then we talk about what will we
do now, in order to return to normal.

264
00:14:32,940 --> 00:14:36,297
And so, we'll talk about
the differences in these approaches,

265
00:14:36,297 --> 00:14:40,204
the modeling that takes place,
the business impact analysis, and the risk

266
00:14:40,204 --> 00:14:44,499
management that has to take place, as well
as the awareness that has to take place.

267
00:14:44,499 --> 00:14:49,399
Not just on the part of the practitioner,
but on the part of every person that plays

268
00:14:49,399 --> 00:14:53,782
some role in the business in terms
of what their role is in this plan.

269
00:14:53,782 --> 00:14:58,820
And when we talk about BCP,
we talk about DRP, we talk about this idea

270
00:14:58,820 --> 00:15:03,520
that it comes down to being aware of
what should happen at critical moments

271
00:15:03,520 --> 00:15:07,730
to make sure that bad things are not
happening because we're not aware of them.

272
00:15:07,730 --> 00:15:10,070
And so we'll talk more about this and
how this works.

273
00:15:10,070 --> 00:15:11,030
Pretty fun discussion,

274
00:15:11,030 --> 00:15:13,800
actually a lot of really interesting
stuff that goes on there.

275
00:15:13,800 --> 00:15:17,860
Legal, regulatory, investigative,
and compliance concerns and areas.

276
00:15:17,860 --> 00:15:19,230
What are legal issues?

277
00:15:19,230 --> 00:15:22,870
What are the processes from
a forensics standpoint, for instance,

278
00:15:22,870 --> 00:15:27,450
that we go through to manage through
perhaps the investigation of an incident,

279
00:15:27,450 --> 00:15:29,110
or an event or a crime?

280
00:15:29,110 --> 00:15:32,250
How do we measure what is
going on through logging and

281
00:15:32,250 --> 00:15:34,740
how do we measure things
through evidence gathering?

282
00:15:34,740 --> 00:15:38,190
So, chain of custody of evidence,
steps involved with that.

283
00:15:38,190 --> 00:15:42,150
Will be very interesting and, obviously,
a part of our conversation there.

284
00:15:42,150 --> 00:15:45,835
This is the area where most people
look at what we do as CISSP's and

285
00:15:45,835 --> 00:15:48,783
think, well I see that on
reality TV all the time, or

286
00:15:48,783 --> 00:15:52,335
I see that on TV shows cuz that's
that whole CSI thing, right?

287
00:15:52,335 --> 00:15:56,946
That's where you guys walk around
with all the cool technology and

288
00:15:56,946 --> 00:16:00,087
maybe carry guns and
get to ride in cool cars.

289
00:16:00,087 --> 00:16:03,912
Quite the opposite actually as you will
hear me go on about when we get into

290
00:16:03,912 --> 00:16:05,054
these discussions.

291
00:16:05,054 --> 00:16:08,508
It is very fascinating work,
it's work I love to do.

292
00:16:08,508 --> 00:16:12,699
It's work that anybody that has a passion
for that area of our field will tell you

293
00:16:12,699 --> 00:16:16,100
can be incredibly fascinating,
incredibly rewarding.

294
00:16:16,100 --> 00:16:20,710
But it is very detail oriented,
it is very precise, it is very focused and

295
00:16:20,710 --> 00:16:23,860
unfortunately to burst your bubble,
it can be a little bit

296
00:16:23,860 --> 00:16:27,690
tedious in the sense that it's not quite
as exciting as you may think it is.

297
00:16:27,690 --> 00:16:32,048
You sit in a cube of some sort, in a room,
wherever that may be, working on this

298
00:16:32,048 --> 00:16:36,498
information more so, than typically doing
it in the field the way you see on TV.

299
00:16:36,498 --> 00:16:40,805
And we don't tend to have the million
dollar AV suite associated with our

300
00:16:40,805 --> 00:16:41,960
workspaces.

301
00:16:41,960 --> 00:16:46,940
So we don't get to perhaps play with some
of those toys that you may see on TV, but

302
00:16:46,940 --> 00:16:49,870
we do a lot of really interesting
things in this kind of an error.

303
00:16:49,870 --> 00:16:53,791
So we'll talk about what does go on and
what those particular items may be?

304
00:16:53,791 --> 00:16:55,565
And then finally, physical security.

305
00:16:55,565 --> 00:16:59,240
Physical/Environmental Security,
as you can see down there.

306
00:16:59,240 --> 00:17:02,190
This is where we talk about things
like where do we build the building,

307
00:17:02,190 --> 00:17:05,010
that will house the dad and
how should it be designed?

308
00:17:05,010 --> 00:17:07,010
What kind of systems does it need?

309
00:17:07,010 --> 00:17:11,419
From external gateways such fences,
and guard posts, and

310
00:17:11,419 --> 00:17:16,988
a closed circuit TV and dogs and lighting,
to what do we need on the inside?

311
00:17:16,988 --> 00:17:20,510
So this is where we talk about
things like, do we have man traps?

312
00:17:20,510 --> 00:17:25,160
And if we have a man trap, do we then also
have monitoring on either side of it?

313
00:17:25,160 --> 00:17:28,750
Either manually driven, somebody who's
literally watching you, make you sign at

314
00:17:28,750 --> 00:17:32,900
a desk as a guard or as an Automator where
we have some sort of scanning system.

315
00:17:32,900 --> 00:17:35,820
So a biometric concern there,
and things like that.

316
00:17:35,820 --> 00:17:38,620
So this is where we get into these kinds
of discussions, this is where we talk

317
00:17:38,620 --> 00:17:41,750
about how to build and
how to designed these secure environments?

318
00:17:41,750 --> 00:17:45,908
So this overall, take together is
the ten bodies of knowledge or

319
00:17:45,908 --> 00:17:50,072
the ten domain areas,
that make up the focal point of the CISSP.

320
00:17:50,072 --> 00:17:53,440
So want to encourage you to be thinking
about, what it takes to become a CISSP.

321
00:17:53,440 --> 00:17:57,530
You're gonna need to become at some level,
as we've said, conversant with and

322
00:17:57,530 --> 00:17:59,130
comfortable with this material.

323
00:17:59,130 --> 00:18:03,140
We're gonna spend a lot of time, both
myself and my co-host as we work through

324
00:18:03,140 --> 00:18:07,260
these episodes and these areas with you,
helping you to better understand them.

325
00:18:07,260 --> 00:18:10,710
But we're also gonna make sure,
hopefully, that you have some questions.

326
00:18:10,710 --> 00:18:13,910
And along the way you ask us those, and
I know Don is always very good about

327
00:18:13,910 --> 00:18:16,310
setting us up to deal with people
that may be in the chat room, and

328
00:18:16,310 --> 00:18:19,110
may have questions that
they wanna proffer to us.

329
00:18:19,110 --> 00:18:23,900
What I think will be valuable for you, and
what I think will be very interesting for

330
00:18:23,900 --> 00:18:27,320
you to do as you go through this material,
as we help work through it with you,

331
00:18:27,320 --> 00:18:30,070
is to make sure that you figure
out how to personalize this?

332
00:18:30,070 --> 00:18:34,070
So what I mean is, bring it down to
your level in your world and help you to

333
00:18:34,070 --> 00:18:38,870
understand, what something like a security
policy means, because it's what you do.

334
00:18:38,870 --> 00:18:42,070
And your example of whatever
a security policy is in your world,

335
00:18:42,070 --> 00:18:43,810
will help you to better
understand this material.

336
00:18:43,810 --> 00:18:46,580
So look for
those places to engage, look for

337
00:18:46,580 --> 00:18:50,190
those places to make it personal, look for
the kind of things that will help you to

338
00:18:50,190 --> 00:18:54,660
better understand what challenges you
may face as you prepare for this exam.

339
00:18:54,660 --> 00:18:57,380
Ask those questions, but
also seek out that knowledge.

340
00:18:57,380 --> 00:19:00,460
Pay attention to the things we offer,
opportunities and tips for

341
00:19:00,460 --> 00:19:01,740
you to follow up.

342
00:19:01,740 --> 00:19:06,310
And most importantly, as we work through
this material, think about as I said,

343
00:19:06,310 --> 00:19:09,080
how you prepare to study for
this kind of an exam?

344
00:19:09,080 --> 00:19:12,560
We'll talk more about that or
the methodology is at some point.

345
00:19:12,560 --> 00:19:16,870
But at a high level, 250 questions,
multiple choice exam.

346
00:19:16,870 --> 00:19:19,290
You'll back in the old day,
back in the old school days,

347
00:19:19,290 --> 00:19:21,110
this was a paper based exam.

348
00:19:21,110 --> 00:19:22,880
You sat for six hours in a room.

349
00:19:22,880 --> 00:19:26,340
You did a Scantron bubble sheet where
you had to bubble in your answers,

350
00:19:26,340 --> 00:19:29,580
much like we would have done on any of
the standardized tests you may have taken,

351
00:19:29,580 --> 00:19:33,960
if you took testing at some point
in your early academic career.

352
00:19:33,960 --> 00:19:37,000
Now, it is computer based, so it is
a little bit of a different experience.

353
00:19:37,000 --> 00:19:40,600
Still six hours in length however,
still 250 questions,

354
00:19:40,600 --> 00:19:44,320
still one of the longest
professional exams in our industry.

355
00:19:44,320 --> 00:19:48,100
Still often thought of by anybody who's
gone through it, as being both one of

356
00:19:48,100 --> 00:19:52,750
the most difficult but
also something that they didn't expect.

357
00:19:52,750 --> 00:19:56,420
When you often hear from people about what
they did in the exam, and how they kinda

358
00:19:56,420 --> 00:19:59,170
went through what they think, that's how
you know I spent all this time studying.

359
00:19:59,170 --> 00:20:01,875
It was as tough as I thought it would be,
but it was fair.

360
00:20:01,875 --> 00:20:03,865
But it was also not what I expected.

361
00:20:03,865 --> 00:20:07,515
And it was a little bit different, didn't
really see some of those questions coming,

362
00:20:07,515 --> 00:20:08,967
they were out of left field maybe.

363
00:20:08,967 --> 00:20:12,650
Or I thought it was going to be like this,
and I really saw it this way.

364
00:20:12,650 --> 00:20:14,780
So it's all multiple choice driven.

365
00:20:14,780 --> 00:20:16,240
What that means is at the end of the day,

366
00:20:16,240 --> 00:20:18,320
you have a series of
questions you must answer.

367
00:20:18,320 --> 00:20:22,980
Some of them will be scenario based, so
there are scenario based exam solutions

368
00:20:22,980 --> 00:20:27,000
these days that were not in older
versions of the exam, but there are now.

369
00:20:27,000 --> 00:20:30,480
Meeting a series of questions built
around a topographical map of knowledge,

370
00:20:30,480 --> 00:20:34,540
typically a couple of paragraphs that
explain a story or some sort of set of

371
00:20:34,540 --> 00:20:38,360
events to you which are then asked to
answer a series of questions about.

372
00:20:38,360 --> 00:20:40,550
But at the end of the day,
this is what an exam means.

373
00:20:40,550 --> 00:20:44,290
It means sitting in a room, and
bringing that knowledge to the fore, and

374
00:20:44,290 --> 00:20:47,210
applying it appropriately within the
scenario that you're given on the screen.

375
00:20:47,210 --> 00:20:50,520
It does also mean for
you, to be very careful,

376
00:20:50,520 --> 00:20:54,630
bringing in that external knowledge
that we all know we all have, and

377
00:20:54,630 --> 00:20:58,780
we all master in our normal
professional practices, and

378
00:20:58,780 --> 00:21:03,050
making it filter through that appropriate
lens of, is this exam appropriate?

379
00:21:03,050 --> 00:21:05,170
Is this real world appropriate?

380
00:21:05,170 --> 00:21:07,970
You in other words will know a lot of
things from the real world that may or

381
00:21:07,970 --> 00:21:10,330
not be focused on in the exam.

382
00:21:10,330 --> 00:21:13,300
And what you often hear from people that
are challenged by an exam like this,

383
00:21:13,300 --> 00:21:17,360
is that they really did a poor
job of time management.

384
00:21:17,360 --> 00:21:20,585
They did a poor job of knowledge
management, and as a result of one or

385
00:21:20,585 --> 00:21:22,505
both of those areas not lining up,

386
00:21:22,505 --> 00:21:25,805
they unfortunately get invited
back to do it again a second time.

387
00:21:25,805 --> 00:21:28,485
And we don't want that to be
the case with any of you.

388
00:21:28,485 --> 00:21:31,035
And so make sure you're thinking
about how to be successful,

389
00:21:31,035 --> 00:21:33,580
along with how you're gonna
master this material?

390
00:21:33,580 --> 00:21:36,910
>> Now, one thing I want to make
sure we touch on before we wrap up,

391
00:21:36,910 --> 00:21:40,750
is that the CISSP certification is not for
everyone.

392
00:21:40,750 --> 00:21:42,730
And I kind of alluded to this,
earlier in the segment,

393
00:21:42,730 --> 00:21:46,220
where I said, if you're just getting
started, if you're interested in

394
00:21:46,220 --> 00:21:51,820
pursuing a career in IT security,
the CISSP is not a starting point.

395
00:21:51,820 --> 00:21:53,570
CISSP is a finish point.

396
00:21:53,570 --> 00:21:55,000
So if you're just getting started,

397
00:21:55,000 --> 00:21:57,380
you might want to look at some of
the other certifications that we have,

398
00:21:57,380 --> 00:22:03,560
like the CompTIA Security+ or ISC Squared,
the SSCP, that's a great starting point.

399
00:22:03,560 --> 00:22:07,980
SSCP is really designed for someone
with a year of experience, but someone

400
00:22:07,980 --> 00:22:12,742
going into the CISSP is expected to
have a far greater amount of experience.

401
00:22:12,742 --> 00:22:16,140
And so I just got up here on the screen
some of the different types of

402
00:22:16,140 --> 00:22:17,620
people that might seek this.

403
00:22:17,620 --> 00:22:21,280
But if you look down the list, you'll
see that word manager a couple times.

404
00:22:21,280 --> 00:22:26,310
These are people who are working full time
in IT security that are moving up to that

405
00:22:26,310 --> 00:22:29,460
higher level in their career,
that's really what the CISSP is all about.

406
00:22:31,260 --> 00:22:34,573
>> [COUGH] It is, and beyond the CISSP
you made reference in the fact that it's

407
00:22:34,573 --> 00:22:36,610
not a starting point or
rather and end point.

408
00:22:36,610 --> 00:22:39,390
And what I think is also important is,
[COUGH]

409
00:22:39,390 --> 00:22:42,960
if you could scroll down just a little
bit on that page while we're talking.

410
00:22:42,960 --> 00:22:46,980
Below this area, advance beyond the CISSP,
if you could bring that up for

411
00:22:46,980 --> 00:22:47,500
just a minute.

412
00:22:47,500 --> 00:22:50,770
So the other thing that's
interesting about ISC squared and

413
00:22:50,770 --> 00:22:55,230
about this certification, is that CISSP in
it of itself is a tremendous achievemen.

414
00:22:55,230 --> 00:22:58,600
The gold standard, the pinnacle of
information security management.

415
00:22:58,600 --> 00:23:03,420
There are over 100,000 CISSPs certified
in the world today, and it is by and

416
00:23:03,420 --> 00:23:08,040
far and away the single most important
certification we have in our industry

417
00:23:08,040 --> 00:23:09,650
in this particular regard.

418
00:23:09,650 --> 00:23:12,963
But having said that, there are areas
you go out beyond the CISSP.

419
00:23:12,963 --> 00:23:16,045
And these are what are called
the concentration areas and so

420
00:23:16,045 --> 00:23:19,570
you can see ISSAP,
which is the architecture professional.

421
00:23:19,570 --> 00:23:22,420
The EP, the Engineering Professional,
the MP the Management or

422
00:23:22,420 --> 00:23:23,930
Managerial Professional.

423
00:23:23,930 --> 00:23:28,540
You must first hold the CISSP in order
to then go on and attain one of these.

424
00:23:28,540 --> 00:23:32,050
What we want you to do is really have a
full sense of what a career in information

425
00:23:32,050 --> 00:23:33,070
security management and

426
00:23:33,070 --> 00:23:36,310
information security as
a practitioner may mean for you?

427
00:23:36,310 --> 00:23:39,460
And becoming a CISSP is not an end point

428
00:23:39,460 --> 00:23:41,780
in that professional development arch for
you.

429
00:23:41,780 --> 00:23:45,690
But rather is a very,
very important plateau that you reach, and

430
00:23:45,690 --> 00:23:47,320
celebrate success around.

431
00:23:47,320 --> 00:23:51,450
And build the foundation of
additional successes from.

432
00:23:51,450 --> 00:23:54,016
But there are other places to go,
and other things to do.

433
00:23:54,016 --> 00:23:57,677
And so while this is a very,
very important milestone in your career,

434
00:23:57,677 --> 00:24:01,588
should you choose to pursue it and
ultimately be successful at it- You will

435
00:24:01,588 --> 00:24:06,000
have other opportunities to pursue
additional certification out beyond this.

436
00:24:06,000 --> 00:24:08,690
We're not really gonna get into what
these credentials mean today, nor

437
00:24:08,690 --> 00:24:12,830
are we gonna really touch on them
anywhere in this set of discussions.

438
00:24:12,830 --> 00:24:16,550
But at least an awareness of the fact
that there are other opportunities inside

439
00:24:16,550 --> 00:24:18,850
of your professional development arc,

440
00:24:18,850 --> 00:24:22,670
you do need to bring CPEs to
the table in order to stay certified.

441
00:24:22,670 --> 00:24:27,640
And the idea here is that as a CISSP,
or even as an SSCP as Don mentioned,

442
00:24:27,640 --> 00:24:31,630
as a starting point, you have to bring a
certain amount of professional development

443
00:24:31,630 --> 00:24:35,770
to your career arc as you go through and
stay a certified professional.

444
00:24:35,770 --> 00:24:40,680
When you certify as a CISSP, you have
a three year lifecycle on your credential.

445
00:24:40,680 --> 00:24:45,310
And what that means is ultimately,
that every three years you will be

446
00:24:45,310 --> 00:24:48,960
asked to validate that you have achieved
a certain amount of additional knowledge

447
00:24:48,960 --> 00:24:52,270
through continuing education
in your career field.

448
00:24:52,270 --> 00:24:54,130
And as a result of that, you will then,

449
00:24:54,130 --> 00:24:55,750
I think it's right there,
it's what you're looking for.

450
00:24:55,750 --> 00:24:56,620
>> I know, I can't seem to find it.

451
00:24:56,620 --> 00:24:57,415
>> 120 CPEs, right?

452
00:24:57,415 --> 00:24:57,930
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

453
00:24:57,930 --> 00:25:01,200
So we want, we're gonna have 120 CPEs,
ultimately,

454
00:25:01,200 --> 00:25:04,460
Continuing Professional Education
credits that are available to you.

455
00:25:04,460 --> 00:25:08,550
Meaning you, as a professional,
have to go out and find opportunities,

456
00:25:08,550 --> 00:25:12,760
attend conferences, read articles,
engage in projects.

457
00:25:12,760 --> 00:25:15,120
There's a million ways to earn CPEs.

458
00:25:15,120 --> 00:25:18,600
You have to do 120 every three years,
which means 40 a year, and

459
00:25:18,600 --> 00:25:23,460
you report those in and randomly you may
or may not be audited by ISC squared.

460
00:25:23,460 --> 00:25:26,080
Auditing just simply means you
have to document what you did.

461
00:25:26,080 --> 00:25:29,740
Other is code of ethics we subscribe to
as information security professionals.

462
00:25:29,740 --> 00:25:33,470
Part of that means you will report
accurately and honestly your activities,

463
00:25:33,470 --> 00:25:35,250
and as a result, be able to validate them.

464
00:25:35,250 --> 00:25:38,690
There's a small fee as you can see,
every year, of $85.00 currently.

465
00:25:38,690 --> 00:25:41,600
For your annual membership fee,
that's what the AMF is for.

466
00:25:41,600 --> 00:25:44,420
And so once you do that,
you don't have to re-certify,

467
00:25:44,420 --> 00:25:47,410
you don't have to retake this
exam as long as you stay current.

468
00:25:47,410 --> 00:25:48,560
There are people, believe it or not,

469
00:25:48,560 --> 00:25:51,560
that actually choose to take this
exam every three years to re-validate

470
00:25:51,560 --> 00:25:55,200
their skills, and that is fine and
there's nothing wrong with that, but

471
00:25:55,200 --> 00:25:58,820
you do have the option to simply I'll
offer these credits up, have them audited,

472
00:25:58,820 --> 00:26:01,950
make sure they are valid, and
then continue on your certification path.

473
00:26:01,950 --> 00:26:05,780
I've been an ISC2,
a proud member of the ISC2 community,

474
00:26:05,780 --> 00:26:10,270
in terms of being an information security
professional for well over a decade, and

475
00:26:10,270 --> 00:26:14,700
I took my exams like everybody else
does at some point in their career, but

476
00:26:14,700 --> 00:26:16,600
I did not go back and
choose to retake them.

477
00:26:16,600 --> 00:26:19,940
I chose to do what most people do,
I will say.

478
00:26:19,940 --> 00:26:23,660
Which is have perhaps less
resistance than others.

479
00:26:23,660 --> 00:26:28,185
Which is to continue to amass CPE credits
every year, report them faithfully and

480
00:26:28,185 --> 00:26:28,935
dutifully.

481
00:26:28,935 --> 00:26:31,825
I do the same thing in my other
professional certifications

482
00:26:31,825 --> 00:26:32,945
that require it.

483
00:26:32,945 --> 00:26:35,025
I am an auditor, for instance,
a certified auditor,

484
00:26:35,025 --> 00:26:40,315
so in my Osaka based credentials that I
hold there, I have to report CPEs as well.

485
00:26:40,315 --> 00:26:43,855
And so it's the same process, and
as I said, there's a very long list of

486
00:26:43,855 --> 00:26:47,655
the activities you can engage in that will
allow you to maintain and gather CPEs.

487
00:26:47,655 --> 00:26:49,565
So just make sure you're aware of that.

488
00:26:49,565 --> 00:26:52,920
And the good news is most of what you
do everyday in a professional practice,

489
00:26:52,920 --> 00:26:56,430
meaning, doing your job will
qualify you at some level for CPE.

490
00:26:56,430 --> 00:26:59,610
So, it's not as if you necessarily
need to go out of your way

491
00:26:59,610 --> 00:27:00,460
in order to gather them.

492
00:27:00,460 --> 00:27:03,980
But it is a requirement, you do wanna
make sure you are aware of that as part

493
00:27:03,980 --> 00:27:07,090
of the overall knowledge we're
gathering here initially.

494
00:27:07,090 --> 00:27:09,470
>> Yeah, I don't think most people
want to sit in that testing booth for

495
00:27:09,470 --> 00:27:12,090
another six hours after doing it once.

496
00:27:12,090 --> 00:27:12,950
>> No, no, no.

497
00:27:12,950 --> 00:27:16,380
No, it is a long day,
let's put it that way, and it is one that.

498
00:27:16,380 --> 00:27:20,540
It really test your metal,
as an individual,

499
00:27:20,540 --> 00:27:22,590
as a practitioner, as a professional.

500
00:27:22,590 --> 00:27:25,760
It makes you really understand
the value of what you do every day, but

501
00:27:25,760 --> 00:27:28,970
it is not by any means unachievable and
unattainable.

502
00:27:28,970 --> 00:27:33,830
People that go through certification exams
hopefully are prepared for the outcome,

503
00:27:33,830 --> 00:27:36,370
meaning they have practiced and
prepared for success.

504
00:27:36,370 --> 00:27:40,230
And if you put the time in up front,
go through the training materials with us.

505
00:27:40,230 --> 00:27:44,040
Do the additional work that's required to
really study and master this material.

506
00:27:44,040 --> 00:27:47,090
You will be successful, and
you will be successful on your first try.

507
00:27:47,090 --> 00:27:48,960
I am not going to promise you that.

508
00:27:48,960 --> 00:27:50,590
But I am going to tell you strongly,

509
00:27:50,590 --> 00:27:53,810
given the experience I have over
almost two decades of doing

510
00:27:53,810 --> 00:27:58,150
this professionally as an educator, that
people that prepare, will be successful.

511
00:27:58,150 --> 00:27:59,790
But you gotta do the work.

512
00:27:59,790 --> 00:28:01,480
And you gotta prepare seriously.

513
00:28:01,480 --> 00:28:03,240
And you gotta understand
how to be successful.

514
00:28:03,240 --> 00:28:04,180
And that's gonna be very important.

515
00:28:05,490 --> 00:28:08,670
>> All right, well I think that's a pretty
good overview of the certification, and so

516
00:28:08,670 --> 00:28:11,360
I just wanted to give everybody a chance
to kinda learn a little bit more about

517
00:28:11,360 --> 00:28:14,780
CISSP, see what it's about, and
determine if it's right for you.

518
00:28:14,780 --> 00:28:18,510
If you wanna pursue it, if this is one of
your goals and you're working towards it,

519
00:28:18,510 --> 00:28:21,390
well, stay tuned, because we're
about to launch our whole series.

520
00:28:21,390 --> 00:28:23,580
We're gonna move through
all of the ten domains and

521
00:28:23,580 --> 00:28:26,600
cover all the different information,
really go into that in depth.

522
00:28:26,600 --> 00:28:29,990
It's a great learning experience even
if you don't ultimately take the exam.

523
00:28:29,990 --> 00:28:31,500
It is a wealth of knowledge.

524
00:28:31,500 --> 00:28:35,375
It's very useful, very practical, and
easy to apply in your work environment.

525
00:28:35,375 --> 00:28:38,533
Take advantage of it, and
we hope to see you then.

526
00:28:38,533 --> 00:28:40,077
>> See you soon.

527
00:28:40,077 --> 00:28:44,540
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don discuss physical and logical access controls and how they can be implemented in a corporate environment. They also take a deeper look into authentication and the assorted components that can be used to build an authentication scheme.
episodes.title: Access Controls

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike cover several different access control models. They discuss different access control systems that implement these models.
episodes.title: Access Controls Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don describe some of the fundamental concepts of computer networking. They demonstrate the function and construction of an IP address and explore the OSI model.
episodes.title: Telecom and Network Security

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike take a look at protocols and port numbers. They also discuss some of the media types and transmission methods as well as several interconnectivity devices such as firewalls and routers.
episodes.title: Telecom and Network Security Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don complete the networking trilogy. They cover a laundry list of acronyms that may show up on the exam. They end the show taking a look at security protocols and wireless technologies.
episodes.title: Telecom and Network Security Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike discuss some of the fundamentals of security. They cover several different control types as well as take a thorough examine of the risk analysis and management approaches.
episodes.title: Risk and Governance

topics.title: Information Security Governance and Risk Management

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike take a look at the different phases associated with the software development lifecycle. They break down some of the key components existing in each phase.
episodes.title: Software Development

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike take a closer look at the security side of software development. They discuss system development lifecycle models and well as software development lifecycle. They cover several different software development models where they would be appropriate to implement.
episodes.title: Software Development Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike introduce us to the classifications and components of cryptography. They discuss different encryptions such as One-time pads as well as various ciphers such as 3DES and AES.
episodes.title: Cryptography

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don examine the assorted encryption and hashing algorithms that you need to know for the exam. They break them down by type and explain their various features and functions. They wrap up by doing a demonstration of hashing functions and how they work.
episodes.title: Cryptography Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike take a look at security protocols such as IPSec and HTTPS. They also cover several types of attacks against crypto systems.
episodes.title: Cryptography Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don break down the various components that make up computer architecture. They identity the functions of a CPU, RAM and storage. They then examine they interaction between the components and modern operating systems.
episodes.title: Security Architecture & Design

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike wrap up the inner works of modern PC components with discussions on Limit Registers, RAM as well as types of ROM. They then conclude with detailing security models, security modes, and systems evaluation methods.
episodes.title: Security Architecture & Design Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike discuss several types of operational security methods. They describe how these methods play a role in a business security environment. They also take a look at vulnerability and penetration testing methods and vulnerability types.
episodes.title: Operations Security

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don describe the various components that make up a disaster recovery plan and a business resumption plan. They highlight some of the various scenarios that need to be planned for and explain some the solution to common situations.
episodes.title: BCP and DRP

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike continue the discussion of business continuity and disaster recovery plans. They take a look at some of the terms every security professional should be familiar with.
episodes.title: BCP and DRP Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike introduce us to the legal aspects of information security. They discuss various regulations and compliance standards as well as investigation procedures and implications.
episodes.title: Legal

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Don describe the uses and handling procedures for the various types of evidence. They also describe the basic principles of computer forensics and chain of custody.
episodes.title: Legal Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Mike describe the various components of physical security such as mantraps and bollards. They also cover environmental security such as natural disasters. They discuss several ways to implement control to help protect the network from both.
episodes.title: Physical and Environmental Security
